Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Regional Interaction as World-System Incorporation in Classic Period Mesoamerica

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers seek to understand how interaction between large states and small polities impacts populations of said small polities at the local and regional level. With increased global interconnectedness and the continued development of world-wide economic systems, the impacts of these systems on local populations, both positive and negative, have become an increasingly important focus of study. Archaeology is particularly well-suited to examine similar processes of interaction in the past and can therefore inform on these processes of economic and political expansion in the present. In the Classic Period (AD 300-900) of ancient Mesoamerica, the large city of Teotihuacan (located near present-day Mexico City), engaged in various forms of contact with many other regions. Forms of interaction included trade, conquest, and cultural dissemination. This project will focus on one location of interaction with Teotihuacan, the Sierra de los Tuxtlas Region of Southern Veracruz, Mexico. It will address the impacts of Teotihuacan influence on local populations in the region and assess the ways in which this influence altered regional social and economic systems. In doing so, this project will contribute to the general study of economic expansion and implements an approach to examine foreign-induced regional economic change from the local perspective, which can be applied broadly. This research will be conducted by Arizona State University doctoral student Nathan D. Wilson, under the direction of Dr. Michael E. Smith. Data from this project will serve as the basis for Mr. Wilson's doctoral dissertation.

This research addresses the issue of peripheral incorporation into larger systems and how this process is manifest regionally. It implements a world-systems framework in quantifying interaction between core-affiliated populations and a negotiated periphery. To evaluate this, it will study peripheral consumption of imported goods in the Western Tuxtlas Region (WTR) of southern Veracruz, Mexico. Through multiple lines of evidence, this research will ascertain the regional economic effects for two WTR polities that were connected to an intrusive center (Matacapan) displaying cultural affiliation to the Mexican highland capital of Teotihuacan. Prior research in the region has focused on intensive production and regional, interpolity distribution of specific pottery types associated with Matacapan. This project will build upon this previous research by: (1) more effectively quantifying consumption of these products in two neighboring polities and (2) assessing distribution and consumption of other Matacapan-produced goods. In doing so, it will construct a regional, diachronic view of the different ways through which these two indigenous polities (and different populations within one of the polities) incorporated into a Teotihuacan world-system via interaction with Matacapan. The proposed research is geared toward analytical methods (e.g., attribute analysis, Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis [INAA], and petrography) to help differentiate between Early and Middle Classic Period contexts, assess the accuracy of visual sourcing of obsidian, and separate local utilitarian pottery types from imported versions. Sample selection from previously excavated materials will be done in Mexico, while sample preparation and chemical and mineralogical analyses will be completed by laboratories in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the direction of Dr. Michael E. Smith, Nathan Wilson analyzed pottery and obsidian artifacts from numerous prehispanic settlements located in the Sierra de los Tuxtlas region of Southern Veracruz, Mexico. Based on prior research in the region, some evidence for the alteration of regional economic systems had been identified. This alteration consisted of changes in regional distribution networks and was associated with the arrival of foreigners from the Mexican Central Highland city of Teotihuacan. The specific objectives of this project were to identify and quantify changes in regional economic systems spanning the Early Classic and Middle Classic periods (A.D. 300-650) in order to measure accurately the regional economic impact on local indigenous polities and their response to said impact.

 

To complete these objectives, this project focused on four artifact types that were conducive to sourcing analyses. Specific analyses were employed to differentiate locally-produced items from imported items. Activities completed with the support of the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant consisted of the acquisition, transport, and analysis of archaeological artifacts. Both chemical and mineralogical analyses were employed in this study. These analyses were selected based on their ability to identify the sources or original production areas for each artifact. A total of 575 artifacts were subjected to these analyses and the results were extended onto the larger artifact collections.

 

Results of these analyses indicate the existence of two regional distribution networks that formed in the Middle Classic Period. One network (Coarse Orange pottery) appears to have been open to all consumers while the other (obsidian blades) was restricted to certain settlements within the region. The latter network also indicates that elites had preferential access. An additional outcome of this research was the identification of imported pottery from a greater number of producers than had been identified in prior research.

 

Results of this research have been disseminated through presentations at academic conferences and through a number of (forthcoming) publications, two of which have been submitted. Data from this research are also in the process of being uploaded to the Digital Archaeological Record (tDAR) so that they can be made available to other scholars.

 

Within archaeology, this project contributes to the study of ancient societies in multiple ways. It characterizes changes in regional interaction in the Tuxtlas Region and provides a multi-faceted approach to the study of interaction in identifying and evaluating distribution networks individually. It also provides further evidence for the efficacy of chemical and mineralogical analyses in archaeology. For Mesoamerican studies, it contributes to the growing understanding of the diverse nature of Teotihuacan influence. Many studies have focused on direct relationships between the Central Highland capital of Teotihuacan and other areas of Mesoamerica. The research completed focuses on regional effects of this contact. It provides a regionally-based, indirect study of Teotihuacan influence in the southern Gulf Coast of Mexico.

 

This project also has relevance to interaction studies and world-systems analysis. With technological advances in communication and trade, the world has become increasingly globalized. Interconnections within this larger global system have increased in both strength and number. As these processes have continued, the impact of globalization on local populations has become a topic of increasing interest. How populations become incorporated into larger systems, and the effects of this incorporation, are important topics of study. To understand better what is both occurring in the present, and what might occur in the future, we need to have sufficient case studies of similar interaction in the past. This project provides such a study, which will be beneficial in contributing to our understanding of local responses to economic changes initiated by outside, or “foreign,” forces.
